curriculum_alignment.nerdc_description: Demand and supply, equilibrium, elasticity, surplus measures

learning_objectives: Define demand and supply and interpret their curves
Explain law of demand and law of supply with determinants
Determine market equilibrium price and quantity
Calculate and interpret price elasticity of demand and supply
Explain consumer and producer surplus with Nigerian market examples

content_sections.title: Demand and Supply Basics
content_sections.content:
**Demand**: quantity consumers are willing and able to buy at different prices (ceteris paribus). **Law of demand**: inverse relation between price and quantity demanded. Demand curve slopes downward.

**Determinants of demand**: income, tastes, price of related goods (substitutes/complements), expectations, population.

**Supply**: quantity producers are willing and able to sell at different prices. **Law of supply**: direct relation between price and quantity supplied. Supply curve slopes upward.

**Determinants of supply**: production cost, technology, taxes/subsidies, price expectations, number of sellers.

**Nigerian context**: Demand for rice rises during festive periods; supply of tomatoes falls in rainy season, raising prices.

content_sections.title: Market Equilibrium and Price Determination
content_sections.content:
Equilibrium occurs where quantity demanded equals quantity supplied (Qd = Qs). At equilibrium price (Pe), there is no surplus or shortage.

**Surplus**: price above Pe, Qs > Qd → downward pressure on price. **Shortage**: price below Pe, Qd > Qs → upward pressure on price.

Shifts vs movements: price change → movement along curve; determinant change → shift of curve.

**Example**: Government fertilizer subsidy shifts supply of maize right, lowering price and raising quantity.

content_sections.title: Elasticity of Demand and Supply
content_sections.content:
**Price Elasticity of Demand (PED)** = % change Qd / % change P.
- |PED| > 1: elastic; |PED| < 1: inelastic; |PED| = 1: unitary.
- Determinants: availability of substitutes, necessity vs luxury, time horizon, budget share.

**Price Elasticity of Supply (PES)** = % change Qs / % change P.
- Determinants: time to respond, spare capacity, storage ability.

**Revenue and PED**: If demand is elastic, price increase lowers revenue; if inelastic, price increase raises revenue (ceteris paribus).

**Nigerian examples**: Petrol demand is relatively inelastic short run; luxury phones elastic; agricultural supply in short run inelastic due to growing season.

content_sections.title: Consumer and Producer Surplus
content_sections.content:
**Consumer surplus**: difference between what consumers are willing to pay and what they actually pay. Area under demand and above price up to quantity bought.

**Producer surplus**: difference between price received and minimum price producers are willing to accept. Area above supply and below price up to quantity sold.

**Total surplus** = consumer surplus + producer surplus; maximized at competitive equilibrium.

**Nigerian market example**: In Balogun market, if competition is strong, prices close to equilibrium maximize total surplus. Price controls (ceilings/floors) can create shortages or surpluses, reducing total surplus.

worked_examples.title: Finding Equilibrium
worked_examples.solution: Set Qd = Qs: 100 - 2P = 20 + 3P → 80 = 5P → P = 16. Q = 100 - 2(16) = 68. Equilibrium: Pe = 16, Qe = 68 units.

worked_examples.title: Elasticity Calculation
worked_examples.context: Price of data bundle rises from N1000 to N1200; quantity demanded falls from 5000GB to 4400GB.

worked_examples.title: Effect of Subsidy on Supply
worked_examples.context: A N50 per unit fertilizer subsidy reduces cost for farmers.
worked_examples.problem: Describe supply shift and price/quantity effects.
worked_examples.solution: Supply shifts right (downward by subsidy amount). New equilibrium price falls, quantity rises. Farmers receive market price plus subsidy; consumers pay lower price; total surplus rises but has government cost.

practice_problems.answer: As price rises, quantity demanded falls (ceteris paribus).
As price rises, quantity supplied rises (ceteris paribus).
Income, tastes, prices of related goods, expectations, population (any two).

practice_problems.problem: Differentiate movement along demand vs shift in demand.
practice_problems.answer: Movement: caused by price change; Shift: caused by non-price determinants (income, tastes, etc.).

practice_problems.problem: If price is below equilibrium, what occurs?
practice_problems.answer: Shortage; Qd > Qs; price rises toward equilibrium.

practice_problems.problem: Give one Nigerian example of inelastic demand.
practice_problems.answer: Petrol (short run), electricity units, basic food staples (e.g., garri) short run.

practice_problems.problem: If PED = -1.5 and price increases, what happens to total revenue?
practice_problems.answer: Demand is elastic; total revenue falls.
practice_problems.explanation: Price up reduces revenue when elastic.

practice_problems.problem: Compute PES when price rises 5% and quantity supplied rises 2%.
Explain how a price ceiling below Pe affects consumer and producer surplus.
practice_problems.answer: Creates shortage; some consumers gain lower price but others cannot buy; producer surplus falls; total surplus falls; deadweight loss appears.

practice_problems.problem: Draw and label consumer and producer surplus at equilibrium.
practice_problems.answer: Consumer surplus: area under demand and above Pe up to Qe; producer surplus: area above supply and below Pe up to Qe.

glossary.definition: Price where quantity demanded equals quantity supplied.
glossary.example: Market-clearing price in a Lagos market.

glossary.definition: Responsiveness of quantity to a change in another variable (usually price).
glossary.example: PED of petrol ~ inelastic short run.
Bread and yam; butter and margarine.

glossary.definition: Benefit buyers get above what they pay.
glossary.example: Paying N500 for item valued at N800.

exam_style_questions.question: Using a diagram, show the effect of a rightward demand shift on equilibrium price and quantity. Explain possible Nigerian causes of such a shift for beans.
exam_style_questions.answer_guide: Draw demand shift right; Pe and Qe rise. Causes: population growth, higher income, preference changes, substitute price increase.

exam_style_questions.question: Calculate PED with midpoint formula given two price-quantity pairs and interpret result for a Nigerian telecom product.
exam_style_questions.answer_guide: Compute %ΔQ and %ΔP, divide. Interpret as elastic/inelastic and relate to revenue strategy.
